articles.headline: The Price Whistle-Blowers Pay for Secrets
articles.snippet: Lawyers and government officials caution would-be whistle-blowers to first understand what they are getting into.
articles.abstract: Lawyers and government officials caution would-be whistle-blowers to first understand what they are getting into.
articles.lead_paragraph: A $104 million award for a whistle-blower is probably enough of an incentive to make most people divulge secrets about their employer, or even their friends, for that matter. The award, the largest ever paid by the Internal Revenue Service, went to Bradley C. Birkenfeld last week for revealing secrets about the Swiss banking system.

articles.headline: Iranian Dissidents Convince U.S. to Drop Terror Label
articles.snippet: The Mujahedeen Khalq, an opposition group that mounted an extraordinary campaign to get off the State Department’s list of terrorist organizations, has succeeded, officials said.
articles.abstract: The Mujahedeen Khalq, an opposition group that mounted an extraordinary campaign to get off the State Department’s list of terrorist organizations, has succeeded, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rarely in the annals of lobbying in the capital has so obscure a cause attracted so stellar a group of supporters: former directors of the C.I.A. and the F.B.I., retired generals and famous politicians of both parties.

articles.headline: From Parents, a Living Inheritance
articles.snippet: Some parents help their adult children financially, while others cannot or do not — and that often unspoken distinction among families can determine who gets ahead.
articles.abstract: Some parents help their adult children financially, while others cannot or do not — and that often unspoken distinction among families can determine who gets ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all of the conversation this week about Mitt Romney’s views on federal income taxes and personal responsibility, his insistence that “I have inherited nothing” may be the most thought-provoking.

articles.headline: BP Offers to Acquire Larger Stake in Rosneft
articles.snippet: The giant oil company BP said it would enlarge the stake if it could first sell its interests in a private joint venture in Russia.
articles.abstract: The giant oil company BP said it would enlarge the stake if it could first sell its interests in a private joint venture in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — BP has offered to acquire a bigger stake in the Russian state oil company Rosneft if it can sell its interests in a private joint venture here, the president of Rosneft said on Friday.

articles.headline: Facebook Can ID Faces, but Using Them Grows Tricky
articles.snippet: The company’s agreement with European regulators to discontinue an automated photo-tagging feature presents a new obstacle over what to do with one of its most vital assets: pictures.
articles.abstract: The company’s agreement with European regulators to discontinue an automated photo-tagging feature presents a new obstacle over what to do with one of its most vital assets: pictures.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook on Friday confronted a new obstacle over what to do with one of its most vital assets — pictures.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Kevin J. O'Brien

articles.headline: To Stay Relevant in a Career, Workers Train Nonstop
articles.snippet: The need to constantly adapt is the new reality for anyone whose job is touched by computing — not just to change careers, but simply to stay competitive on one’s chosen path.
articles.abstract: The need to constantly adapt is the new reality for anyone whose job is touched by computing — not just to change careers, but simply to stay competitive on one’s chosen path.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, Ty Hallock has steered his business from Web site creation to social media to mobile apps. In three more years, he expects to be back at the drawing board again.

articles.headline: Angry Libyans Target Militias, Forcing Flight
articles.snippet: Thousands of Libyans marched through Benghazi and seized control of the headquarters of several militias, demanding that they be disarmed after an American ambassador was killed.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Libyans marched through Benghazi and seized control of the headquarters of several militias, demanding that they be disarmed after an American ambassador was killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Galvanized by anger over the killing of the popular American ambassador here last week, thousands of Libyans marched through this city on Friday, demanding the disarming of the militias that helped topple the dictatorship but have troubled the country with their refusal to disband.
articles.byline: By Suliman Ali Zway and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: At the Track, Racing Economics Collide With Veterinarians’ Oath
articles.snippet: Horse-racing veterinarians are both doctor and drugstore; the more drugs they prescribe, the more money they make.
articles.abstract: Horse-racing veterinarians are both doctor and drugstore; the more drugs they prescribe, the more money they make.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only after Bourbon Bandit broke a leg racing last November did his owner, Susan Kayne, learn the full extent of prescription drugs that veterinarians had given him at Belmont Park on Long Island.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich, Joe Drape and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Medicare Bills Rise as Records Turn Electronic
articles.snippet: The move to electronic health records may be adding billions of dollars to Medicare costs by enabling hospitals and physicians to bill more for the same services.
articles.abstract: The move to electronic health records may be adding billions of dollars to Medicare costs by enabling hospitals and physicians to bill more for the same services.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the federal government began providing billions of dollars in incentives to push hospitals and physicians to use electronic medical and billing records, the goal was not only to improve efficiency and patient safety, but also to reduce health care costs.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson, Julie Creswell and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: Romney Reveals He Paid 14% Rate in 2011 Tax Return
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney responded to months of political pressure on Friday by making public his most recent tax return and limited information from previous years.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney responded to months of political pressure on Friday by making public his most recent tax return and limited information from previous years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney responded to months of political pressure on Friday by making public his most recent tax return and limited information from previous years, asserting that he had paid a double-digit federal income tax rate for more than two decades.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: C.E.O.’s and the Pay-’Em-or-Lose-’Em Myth
articles.snippet: The argument that C.E.O.’s will leave if they aren’t compensated well, perhaps even lavishly, is bogus, according to a new study.
articles.abstract: The argument that C.E.O.’s will leave if they aren’t compensated well, perhaps even lavishly, is bogus, according to a new study.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORPORATIONS are forever defending big executive paydays. If we don’t pay up, the argument goes, our sharpest minds will jump to our rivals.

articles.headline: The Man Who Would Be Redstone
articles.snippet: Philippe P. Dauman, Viacom’s chief executive, has been chosen by its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, as his successor. But Mr. Dauman faces a test in maintaining the company as a huge creative force.
articles.abstract: Philippe P. Dauman, Viacom’s chief executive, has been chosen by its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, as his successor. But Mr. Dauman faces a test in maintaining the company as a huge creative force.
articles.lead_paragraph: FROM up in the carob trees come the strains of great movie themes: the sad hum of “Love Story,” the creepy lull of “Rosemary’s Baby,” the jazzy screech of “Chinatown.” Below, just outside the grand entrance of the building where Adolph Zukor and Cecil B. DeMille once did business, Sumner M. Redstone’s retinue sips Champagne in the hot afternoon sun.

articles.headline: Egypt’s New Leader Spells Out Terms for U.S.-Arab Ties
articles.snippet: On the eve of his first trip to the United States as Egypt’s president, Mohamed Morsi said the United States must fundamentally change its approach to the Arab world.
articles.abstract: On the eve of his first trip to the United States as Egypt’s president, Mohamed Morsi said the United States must fundamentally change its approach to the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — On the eve of his first trip to the United States as Egypt’s new Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi said the United States needed to fundamentally change its approach to the Arab world, showing greater respect for its values and helping build a Palestinian state, if it hoped to overcome decades of pent-up anger.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: An Evangelical Is Back From Exile, Lifting Romney
articles.snippet: Ralph Reed, who turned the Christian Coalition into a powerful political force, is planning a get-out-the-vote operation for Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Ralph Reed, who turned the Christian Coalition into a powerful political force, is planning a get-out-the-vote operation for Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Ga. — Ralph Reed is clearly relishing his revival.

articles.headline: Power, Pollution and the Internet
articles.snippet: Helping to process the staggering amount of Internet activity that occurs, data centers waste vast amounts of energy, belying the information industry’s image of environmental friendliness.
articles.abstract: Helping to process the staggering amount of Internet activity that occurs, data centers waste vast amounts of energy, belying the information industry’s image of environmental friendliness.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Jeff Rothschild’s machines at Facebook had a problem he knew he had to solve immediately. They were about to melt.

articles.headline: In U.S. Exit From Iraq, Failed Efforts and Challenges
articles.snippet: The United States’ goal has been to leave a stable government, avoid a power vacuum and maintain influence, but the Obama administration has fallen short on some objectives.
articles.abstract: The United States’ goal has been to leave a stable government, avoid a power vacuum and maintain influence, but the Obama administration has fallen short on some objectives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The request was an unusual one, and President Obama himself made the confidential phone call to Jalal Talabani, the Iraqi president.

articles.headline: Disruptions: Will Apple Be the First to Break $1 Trillion?
articles.snippet: If Apple continues on its current trajectory, it might break a barrier on April 9, 2015, that no company has ever touched.
articles.abstract: If Apple continues on its current trajectory, it might break a barrier on April 9, 2015, that no company has ever touched.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Apple continues on its current trajectory, something remarkable might happen on April 9, 2015, at around 11 a.m.

articles.headline: Television’s Fall Season Endures
articles.snippet: The idea of a fall season of TV premieres, originally tied to the model year for cars, has survived changing viewer habits and the constant flow of new cable programs.
articles.abstract: The idea of a fall season of TV premieres, originally tied to the model year for cars, has survived changing viewer habits and the constant flow of new cable programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Alan Wurtzel, the head of research for NBC, has questioned the enduring validity of a television season — the ritual competition of network series, which begins again Monday night.

articles.headline: Mobile Services and Cable TV Are Unexpected Allies
articles.snippet: A little-noticed result of Verizon’s $3.9 billion airwave purchase is that cable companies can now use the carrier’s retail presence to sell cable packaged with phone and wireless service.
articles.abstract: A little-noticed result of Verizon’s $3.9 billion airwave purchase is that cable companies can now use the carrier’s retail presence to sell cable packaged with phone and wireless service.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASKING RIDGE, N.J. — Tucked amid rows of office cubicles at the sprawling Verizon Wireless headquarters here and hidden behind a locked door sit the company’s best kept retail secrets.

articles.headline: Deadly Attack in Libya Was Major Blow to C.I.A. Efforts
articles.snippet: Among personnel pulled from Benghazi after the assault on the American mission were intelligence operatives and contractors who were crucial to surveillance on militants.
articles.abstract: Among personnel pulled from Benghazi after the assault on the American mission were intelligence operatives and contractors who were crucial to surveillance on militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans has dealt the Central Intelligence Agency a major setback in its intelligence-gathering efforts at a time of increasing instability in the North African nation.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Liking It or Not, States Prepare for Health Law
articles.snippet: A handful of states whose Republican governors oppose President Obama’s health care overhaul are quietly working to have an insurance exchange ready before the deadline next month to create one.
articles.abstract: A handful of states whose Republican governors oppose President Obama’s health care overhaul are quietly working to have an insurance exchange ready before the deadline next month to create one.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Like many Republican governors, Jan Brewer of Arizona is a stinging critic of President Obama’s health care law. When the Supreme Court upheld it in June, she called the ruling “an overreaching and unaffordable assault on states’ rights and individual liberty.”

articles.headline: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
articles.snippet: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube.
articles.abstract: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Once the best of friends, Google and Apple have become foes, battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace. Last week, the hostilities took a new turn when they spilled right onto smartphone screens.

articles.headline: Running as Outsiders, With a Catch: They’re In
articles.snippet: Members of Congress would prefer not to advertise it — they are doctors and cowboys and anything else, while their opponents are Washington insiders.
articles.abstract: Members of Congress would prefer not to advertise it — they are doctors and cowboys and anything else, while their opponents are Washington insiders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of his campaign advertisements, Joe Heck emphasizes his long career as a physician taking care of elderly patients. Dan Benishek, in an ad, refers with a tinge of sadness to the “career politician” who is competing with him for a House seat. Ann Kirkpatrick informs viewers that she is extremely fond of driving.

articles.headline: Covering the World of Business, Digital Only
articles.snippet: After losing millions as publisher of The Atlantic, David Bradley opts to present business news with Quartz, the media company’s new, strictly digital forum.
articles.abstract: After losing millions as publisher of The Atlantic, David Bradley opts to present business news with Quartz, the media company’s new, strictly digital forum.
articles.lead_paragraph: Business titans are generally not prone to self-appraisal, and when they do take stock, it usually begins and ends with a list of their conquests.

articles.headline: Data Barns in a Farm Town, Gobbling Power and Flexing Muscle
articles.snippet: When Internet factories come to town, they can feel less like their sleek, clean and convenient image and more like old-time manufacturing.
articles.abstract: When Internet factories come to town, they can feel less like their sleek, clean and convenient image and more like old-time manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUINCY, Wash. — Set in the dry hills and irrigated farmland of Central Washington, Grant County is known for its robust harvest of apples, potatoes, cherries and beans. But for Microsoft, a prime lure was the region’s other valuable resource: cheap electrical power.

articles.headline: A Manager of Overseas Crises, as Much as the World Permits
articles.snippet: Gray-suited, meticulous and little known to the public, Tom Donilon is President Obama’s national security adviser and central figure in American foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Gray-suited, meticulous and little known to the public, Tom Donilon is President Obama’s national security adviser and central figure in American foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama flies to New York on Monday afternoon for the United Nations General Assembly, he will dispense with the usual battery of one-on-one meetings with world leaders so he can tape an appearance on “The View” and return by midweek to the battleground state of Ohio. Left to help smooth over any ruffled feathers will be Tom Donilon.

articles.headline: Seeking Allies, Teachers’ Unions Court G.O.P., Too
articles.snippet: As traditional political alliances have shifted, teachers’ unions are navigating a delicate political landscape where they increasingly pursue friends in unlikely places.
articles.abstract: As traditional political alliances have shifted, teachers’ unions are navigating a delicate political landscape where they increasingly pursue friends in unlikely places.
articles.lead_paragraph: The strike by public school teachers in Chicago this month drew national attention to a fierce debate over the future of education and exposed the ruptured relationship between teachers’ unions and Democrats like Mayor Rahm Emanuel.
